title: add  arg.params,aux.params parameters in R. close #1543
body:
arg.params,aux.params parameters are added in mx.model.FeedForward.create function. After adding parameters above, people can load the model from a checkpoint and continue learning by passing parameters symbol, arg.params and aux.params of the model.

An example is pushed which is modified by basic_model.R to test to load model and continue training. Part of the code is below:

``` R
# load the model
model <- mx.model.load("chkpt", 1)

#continue training with some new arguments
model <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(model$symbol, X=dtrain, eval.data=dtest,
                                     ctx=devices, num.round=5,
                                     learning.rate=0.1, momentum=0.9,
                                     epoch.end.callback=mx.callback.save.checkpoint("reload_chkpt"),
                                     batch.end.callback=mx.callback.log.train.metric(100),
                                     arg.params=model$arg.params, aux.params=model$aux.params)

```

title: A fine-tune example on caltech101 from pre-trained vgg16 net
body:
## Add a fine-tune example on caltech101 from pre-trained vgg16 net

`fine-tune/train_imagenet.py` additionally accepts three arguments --dataset='imagenet', --finetune-from=None, --finetune-lr-scale=10. 

If args.dataset == 'imagenet', it is in training mode, otherwise it is in fine-tuning mode. And the last fully connected layers are automatically renamed to `'fc_<dataset>'` if args.dataset != 'imagenet'. The finetune layers are also automatically scaled by args.finetune_lr_scale. 

A simple examples is:

```
python train_imagenet.py --data-dir=caltech101 --dataset=caltech101 --num-classes=102 --num-examples=7315 --model-prefix=finetune_caltech101_vgg16 --finetune-from=vgg16/vgg16-0001 --network=vgg16 --batch-size=20 --lr=0.0005 --gpus=0
```

title: Fix #1323. lr_scheduler, clip_gradient, Xavier initializer are supported for R package
body:
**How**

The Xavier initializer is borrowed from python implementation. This PR enables R package support `factor_type = c('in', 'out', 'avg')` and `rnd_type = c('gaussian', 'uniform')` to generate weights.

`clip_gradient` is implemented via `pmax`/`pmin` R built-in function. 

`lr_scheduler` is referring to python implementation `python/lr_scheduler.py`.  I noticed there is some discussion among your developer team and hopefully my PR makes it as well. If @thirdwing  could revise this PR, it will be appreciated ;-)

**What**

Give a try using the official example:

``` r
# Using regerssion as example to test my xavier initializer

# Data
data(BostonHousing, package="mlbench")
train.ind = seq(1, 506, 3)
train.x = data.matrix(BostonHousing[train.ind, -14])
train.y = BostonHousing[train.ind, 14]
test.x = data.matrix(BostonHousing[-train.ind, -14])
test.y = BostonHousing[-train.ind, 14]

# Computing Symbols
data <- mx.symbol.Variable("data")
fc1 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data, num_hidden=1)
lro <- mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput(fc1)

# Training model
print("Default training")
mx.set.seed(0)
model <-
  mx.model.FeedForward.create(lro, X=train.x, y=train.y,
                              ctx=mx.cpu(), num.round=50, array.batch.size=20,
                              learning.rate=2e-6, momentum=0.9,
                              eval.metric=mx.metric.rmse)


# Prediction using test data
preds <- predict(model, test.x)
# See diff
diff <- sqrt(mean((preds-test.y)^2))

# Training model with Xavier
print("Traing with Xavier initializer")
mx.set.seed(0)
modelX <-
  mx.model.FeedForward.create(lro, X=train.x, y=train.y,
                              ctx=mx.cpu(), num.round=50, array.batch.size=20,
                              learning.rate=2e-6, momentum=0.9,
                              eval.metric=mx.metric.rmse,
                              initializer = mx.init.Xavier(
                                rnd_type = "gaussian",
                                factor_type = "in",
                                magnitude = 2))
predsX <- predict(modelX, test.x)
diffX <- sqrt(mean((predsX - test.y)^2))

# Training model with clipping on gradient
print("Training model with clip")
mx.set.seed(0)
modelC <-
  mx.model.FeedForward.create(lro, X=train.x, y=train.y,
                              ctx=mx.cpu(), num.round=50, array.batch.size=20,
                              learning.rate=2e-6, momentum=0.9,
                              eval.metric=mx.metric.rmse,
                              clip_gradient = 1)
predsC <- predict(modelC, test.x)
diffC <- sqrt(mean((predsC - test.y)^2))

# Training model with clipping on gradient
print("Training model with schedule")
mx.set.seed(0)
modelS <-
  mx.model.FeedForward.create(lro, X=train.x, y=train.y,
                              ctx=mx.cpu(), num.round=50, array.batch.size=20,
                              learning.rate=2e-6, momentum=0.9,
                              eval.metric=mx.metric.rmse,
                              lr_scheduler=FactorScheduler(10, 0.9))

predsS <- predict(modelS, test.x)
diffS <- sqrt(mean((predsS - test.y)^2))

print(diff)
print(diffX)
print(diffC)
print(diffS)
```

```
[1] 7.800502
[1] 7.888685
[1] 16.15398
[1] 8.324275
```

Cc: @thirdwing  as I am interested in participating your GSOC 2016 project.

title: Add some error catch
body: Add some error catch for img2rec.cc. There are some potential problems whiling making rec files from images, such as wrong format of list wrong format of file, decode failing, and file not exists. Any of these problems will break the process of img2rec, and we need to redo the whole process after we fix the problem. This brings us huge inconvenience when we makes very large rec files. So, we have added some error catches in the img2rec.cc, which let us to catch the error of the above problems without breaking the whole process. The program will also create a new list of images for the valid records after the whole process.

title: try to keep memory region alive untill julia handled it.
body:
@piiswrong @pluskid I started addressing native operators in Julia again and I have run into the issue that the memory areas passed to Julia for tags and arrays went out of scope and contained garbage, before Julia got to them. 

This PR is my attempt at fixing this, but it still doesn't work. What would be the best way of waiting till the async operation has finished to then `delete` the pointers?

title: Stochastic Gradient Langevin Dynamics + Bayesian Dark Knowledge examples
body:
# Stochastic Gradient Langevin Dynamics & Bayesian Dark Knowledge Example

Contains examples related to _Stochastic Gradient Langevin Dynamics (SGLD)_ [<cite>(Welling and Teh, 2011)</cite>](http://www.icml-2011.org/papers/398_icmlpaper.pdf)
and _Bayesian Dark Knowledge (BDK)_ [<cite>(Balan, Rathod, Murphy and Welling, 2015)</cite>](http://papers.nips.cc/paper/5965-bayesian-dark-knowledge).

**sgld.ipynb** shows how to use MXNet to repeat the toy experiment in the original paper. **bdk_demo.py** contains scripts related to Bayesian Dark Knowledge. 
Use `python bdk_demo.py -d 1 -l 2 -t 50000` to run classification on MNIST. More details will be added.

See https://github.com/sxjscience/mxnet/blob/bayesian-dark-knowledge/example/bayesian-dark-knowledge/sgld.ipynb for the current notebook. However, the math formulas may not be aligned correctly (see https://github.com/jupyter/nbviewer/issues/452 for similar problems).

title: new DropoutAllchannels operator / layer
body:
This pull request adds a new "DropoutAllchannels" operator, which is intended to work on batches of image or image-like inputs such as the output of convolution operations.

The DropoutAllchannels layer drops or keeps all channels of given pixels, everything else behaves just as usual.  The code is a slight modification of the Dropout operator. It is tested on CPU so far, and seems to work fine. 

NOTE: Yes, this operator could be emulated given existing operators, but that would be rather messy.

title: Bucketing Model API
body:
Bucketing API. In order to use the bucketing API, one need to add the following _extra_ properties to data iter and data batch on top of any existing `DataIter`:
- `DataIter`
  - `default_bucket_key`: the bucket key for the default symbol.
- `DataBatch`
  - `provide_data`: same as `DataIter`, but specific to this batch
  - `provide_label`: same as `DataIter`, but specific to this batch
  - `bucket_key`: the key for the bucket that should be used for this batch

There is a simple sanity check example with mnist in `mnist_bucket.py` -- it creates 3 buckets which are all the same. It also serves a demonstration of how the API works.

I will create an example with ptb language model to demonstrate how bucketing with variable-length sequence model works soon.

title: [Torch] 1 lua_State per Operator instance to fix GC issues
body:
This PR is a potential resolution to #1413.
The original issue is due to the serialization improperly managing references causing memory issues when certain objects get garbage collected. This PR removes the serialization in favour of lua references and dedicated lua_State per operator. This should hopefully make things more transparent as well.

I have tested this with the code in #1413 (with my hack to torch to introduce more GC calls), my original net that was having issues, and examples/torch/*.py.

There is one potential race that could occur with this implementation that I don't think is possible but I want to note it down somewhere anyhow:
Certain torch nn modules store data computed in the forward pass for use in the backward pass on them. These make the assumption that the calls to `forward` and `backward` will be alternating and never called concurrently. I am not sure if I should put in a mutex to ensure this condition is upheld. If backward and forward are called concurrently in this implementation a `CHECK_EQ(lua_gettop(L), 0);`  will most likely fail.

title: enable setting return type for operators in registry
body: Most operators returns one Symbol, but some like slice_channel returns array of Symbols. This patch enables setting return type to "Symbol" or "Symbol[]" in the registry, so that we can get the return type in MXSymbolGetAtomicSymbolInfo()

title: NDSB1 example. Stratified sampling and generation of training curve graph
body:
sorry, this is a continuation of https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/1345, I messed up my fork branch and didn't manage to recover so I make this new PR. (I am new to git/github).

Following @piiswrong recommendation I removed pandas dependencies and made stratified sampling optional, I have also made a better arg parser.

Minor change to the NDSB1 example, adding stratified sampling instead of the "sed" command to split into train and validation.
Also added an example of how to generate the training curves from the log script based on #1302

title: Hybrid Backward
body:
Note: the diff includes changes in #1334.

Provide top-gradient for non-loss output only. This is to support RNN backward, when the symbol is a group of loss nodes and states nodes to be connected to future state inputs. The gradient of a loss node can be computed automatically, while the gradient for the state nodes need to be obtained from future states during BPTT. See the unit test for more details.

title: Partial shape inference
body:
Add an API to do partial shape inference. This is to support shape inference with recurrence. Because the shape of the previous-states are unknown, so shape inference could fail. However, for many cases (e.g. elementwise `+` is used to combine `h2h` and `x2h`), we can do partial inference first and then do full shape inference after we obtain the output shape of the _next_ state. See the unittest for more details.

Previous survey on existing RNN interfaces is also committed here.

title: Add LD_LIBRARY_PATH into search paths for libmxnet.so.
body:
By convention, dynamic objects like `libmxnet.so` are searched in `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` on POSIX platforms. Python seems to ignore this convention, which requires extra hack on the user side, such copying `libmxnet.so` file for each training project. 

I add `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` into search paths, making `libmxnet.so` act more like a standard library.

title: Correct typos.
body:
Thank you for your work. I've successfully built `libmxnet.so` on with GCC+OpenBLAS and ICC+MKL separtately. If I may, I wonder why MKL is required to be statically linked into `libmxnet.so`. Dynamic linking of MKL also makes sense.

My arguments are:
- Just like OpenBLAS, MKL provides BLAS implementation. So MKL can be linked dynamically like OpenBLAS. It doesn't bother users that much to add MKL lib path to `LD_LIBRARY` variable.
- So far I haven't seen posts or experienced issues on using Python backed by dynamically-linked MKL.
- Even MKL is statically linked into `libmxnet.so`, other Intel compiler libraries (libiomp5, libimf, libsvml,..) are still required at runtime.

GCC + OpenBLAS:

```
$ ldd lib/libmxnet.so | grep openblas
libopenblas.so.0 => /lustre/usr/openblas/0.2-gcc49/lib/libopenblas.so.0 (0x00002b637da67000)
```

ICC + MKL

```
$ ldd lib/libmxnet.so | grep intel
    libiomp5.so => /lustre/usr/intel_cluster_studio/composer_xe_2015.2.164/compiler/lib/intel64/libiomp5.so (0x00002b04a3705000)
    libimf.so => /lustre/usr/intel_cluster_studio/composer_xe_2015.2.164/compiler/lib/intel64/libimf.so (0x00002b04a406b000)
    libsvml.so => /lustre/usr/intel_cluster_studio/composer_xe_2015.2.164/compiler/lib/intel64/libsvml.so (0x00002b04a4526000)
    libirng.so => /lustre/usr/intel_cluster_studio/composer_xe_2015.2.164/compiler/lib/intel64/libirng.so (0x00002b04a53fa000)
    libintlc.so.5 => /lustre/usr/intel_cluster_studio/composer_xe_2015.2.164/compiler/lib/intel64/libintlc.so.5 (0x00002b04a5b21000)
```

title: [op] fix
body: @vchuravy for x < 0, forward: outdata = a ( exp(x) - 1), in backward we are calling grad(outdata). As d outdata/dx = a \* exp(x), so grad(outdata) should be: outdata + a
